channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Proposed Abortion Restrictions in Spain Face Backlash
item.description: The proposal would allow the termination of a pregnancy only if it was the result of rape or if having the baby would endanger the mother’s health.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: SÃo Paulo Journal: Brazil’s Latest Clash With Its Urban Youth Takes Place at the Mall
item.description: Authorities are struggling to decide how to handle rolezinhos — rowdy gatherings of young people at shopping malls — as questions abound about its racial, social and class implications.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: At the Plaza shopping mall in Niterói, a suburb of Rio de Janeiro, young people gather in what is known as a rolezinho, or stroll.

item.title: In a City on Okinawa, Mayor’s Re-election Deals a Blow to Marine Base Relocation Plan
item.description: Voters in an Okinawan city re-elected a mayor who promised to block construction of a replacement site for the United States base.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: The fishing hamlet of Henoko, where Marine Corps’ Air Station Futenma is to be relocated.

item.title: Congressional Leaders Suggest Earlier Snowden Link to Russia
item.description: Edward J. Snowden may have worked with Russian spy agencies while he was still a contractor for the National Security Agency, Representative Mike Rogers said.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Olympics Security Worries U.S. Officials
item.description: Several Congressional leaders said Russia was not sharing information about potential terrorist threats to the Games to be held in Sochi next month.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Back in China, Watching One’s Words
item.description: A writer returns to China after spending years in the United States, to find herself in tricky conversations with Chinese relatives and friends.
item.dc:creator: By HELEN GAO
item.media:credit: Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Chinese tourists taking in the sights in New York. Chinese perceptions of the United States, it often seems, are colored by their feelings toward China.

item.title: Iran Welcomes Start of Nuclear Deal
item.description: Iranian leaders said they were encouraged not only by the prospect of economic relief with the lifting of some sanctions, but also by a possible end to the country’s political isolation.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Central African Town Is Left Charred, Empty and Hopeless Amid Violence
item.description: The buildings in Bossangoa are charred and abandoned, with most of the population of 50,000 now in refugee camps, one for Muslims and another for Christians.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: A girl pushed a cart past burning houses in the Central African Republic town of Bossangoa earlier this month. Dozens of villages and parts of towns have been burned down by marauding guerrillas in a fitful sectarian civil war between Christians and Muslims.

item.title: In Ukraine Protests Over New Laws, Sticks and Stones Are Met With Tear Gas
item.description: In the worst violence in at least a month for the continuing protest movement in Ukraine, men in masks clashed with the police over new laws cracking down on public assembly.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Protesters clashed with the police near government buildings in Kiev on Sunday.

item.title: Chris Chataway, 82, Runner and Politician
item.description: Chataway helped Roger Bannister, a fellow Oxford graduate, achieve the first sub-four-minute mile in 1954, and he later became a member of Parliament and a Cabinet minister.
item.dc:creator: By FRANK LITSKY
item.media:description: Roger Bannister, left, with Chris Chataway in 1954 after running the first sub-four-minute mile in Oxford, England.

item.title: The Lede: Twitter Suspends Hamas Accounts
item.description: The accounts were used by the militant wing of the Palestinian government to directly communicate with the Israel Defense Forces during at 2012 bombing campaign.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screenshot of a Twitter exchange between an Israeli military spokesman and the military wing of Hamas on October 22, 2013.

item.title: Two Are Wounded After Israel Unleashes Airstrike in Gaza
item.description: A Palestinian man and a boy were hurt after the Israeli military targeted an Islamic Jihad operative it said had been responsible for recent rocket fire in southern Israel.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Palestinians gathered on Sunday around the wreckage of a motorcycle hit overnight by an Israeli airstrike in Gaza.

item.title: Bangkok Protests Hit by Two Explosions
item.description: More than two dozen people were injured in the blasts that hit an antigovernment demonstration in Bangkok, a further escalation of violence in Thailand’s political crisis.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Police officers on Sunday inspected the site of an attack on antigovernment protesters in Bangkok.

item.title: Deadly Bomb Blast Rocks Pakistan Military Compound
item.description: Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan, an umbrella group for militants, has taken responsibility for a bomb planted inside a vehicle that killed at least 20 people.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Region Boiling, Israel Takes Up Castle Strategy
item.description: As Israel faces threats both from traditional Shiite adversaries like Iran and from extremist Sunni cells in Syria, Iraq and beyond, officials insist they have no inclination to intervene.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: An Israeli security coordinator near Kiryat Shmona stood by the remains of a rocket fired from Lebanon last month.

item.title: Turkey Extends Purge of Officials
item.description: Turkey has fired dozens of banking and telecoms regulators and state television executives in moves that appear to broaden the Prime Minister’s response to a corruption investigation.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Iraq Bombings and Fighting Kill Dozens
item.description: A series of car bombings and fighting between militants and government troops over control of Anbar Province killed at least 30 people Saturday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Q. and A.: In Syria, Former Official Says, ‘Nobody Is Winning’
item.description: Excerpts from an interview with Jihad Makdissi, a former Foreign Ministry spokesman in Syria who fled in 2012 as the government cracked down on protesters.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Ex-Official Claims to Speak for Sidelined Syrians
item.description: Jihad Makdissi, the former Foreign Ministry spokesman, has resurfaced, a rare high-profile dissenter seeking to position himself as a voice for many Syrians who remain on the sidelines.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and HALA DROUBI
item.media:description: Jihad Makdissi, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, in July 2012. He left his post later that year.

item.title: Iran Diplomat Dies in Yemen After Shooting
item.description: Gunmen killed Ali Asghar Asadi, an economic attaché, in a drive-by shooting in the Yemeni capital, Sana, in the latest attack on Iran’s diplomatic corps in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Overwhelming Vote for Egypt’s Constitution Raises Concern
item.description: The voters approved a revised constitution validating last summer’s military takeover and paving the way for Gen. Abdul-Fattah el-Sisi, the country’s top military leader, to seek the presidency.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Intensive Security for Winter Olympics
item.description: As the Winter Games approach, tens of thousands of personnel and surveillance cameras have been deployed to Sochi. Critics say the measures threaten to temper the Olympic spirit.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Cossack officer is among hundreds who are joining regular security forces at Olympic venues like Rosa Khutor, a skiing center.

item.title: 9 in Haiti Accused in Journalist Case
item.description: A judge in Port-au-Prince accused nine people, including friends of former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, of having had a hand in the killing of the radio journalist Jean Dominique.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Greek Prosecutors Focus on Corruption at the Top
item.description: Corruption cases are being pursued against a widening pool of current and former high-ranking government officials and members of the business gentry once deemed untouchable.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:credit: Dimitris Kotsakis/In Time News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Michalis Liapis, a former minister, is accused of using European subsidies to renovate a home.

item.title: After Love Unravels in Media, Indian Politician’s Wife Is Found Dead
item.description: The death of Sunanda Pushkar stunned many in Delhi’s journalistic and political circles, many of whom had followed the twists in her life since she met Shashi Tharoor.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Sunanda Pushkar, left, and Shashi Tharoor at their wedding reception in 2010.
